newsitem.title: GERMANY: German FDP wants full Telekom selloff.
newsitem.headline: German FDP wants full Telekom selloff.

text.p: German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel was quoted on Friday as saying his Free Democrat Party (FDP) wanted Deutsche Telekom AG to be fully privatised to help Bonn achieve lasting budget discipline.
"We can get more out of Telekom. I have nothing against a full privatisation," Kinkel told the Handelsblatt business daily ahead of an FDP party conference.

Telekom, which floated 26 percent of its stock last November in an issue which raised 20 billion marks, would be worth 80 billion marks to the government at its current stock market price, Kinkel said.
Kinkel added that a plan announced last week by Finance Minister Theo Waigel to revalue the Bundesbank's gold reserves had been carried out long ago by other European countries.
Waigel wants to boost the government's financial position by raising the value of the gold reserves, thereby helping to contain state borrowing this year to qualify for European monetary union (EMU).
The Maastricht treaty says countries should trim their budget deficits to three percent of gross domestic product in order to join the single currency's starting lineup in 1999.
Kinkel warned that a delay to EMU would have disastrous consequences for Germany.
"I am deeply convinced that we would suffer a rise in the value of the deutschemark and a devaluation of other currencies," he told Handelsblatt.
"This would have disastrous consequences for jobs. And we would struggle to get anywhere in foreign policy if we do not introduce the euro."
